description: From Latin attenuāre, from attenuāt-, at- = ad-, ad- (“to”) + tenuāre (“to make thin”), tenuis (“thin”).

adjectives.description: attenuate (comparative more attenuate, superlative most attenuate)

entries.meaning: (botany, of leaves) Gradually tapering into a petiole-like extension toward the base.

verbs.description: attenuate (third-person singular simple present attenuates, present participle attenuating, simple past and past participle attenuated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reduce in size, force, value, amount, or degree.
examples: A manor-house clock from the far depths of shadow struck the hour, one, in a small, attenuated tone.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make thinner, as by physically reshaping, starving, or decaying.
examples: Clumps of attenuated turkeys were suspended here and there.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become thin or fine; to grow less.

examples: We may reject and reject till we attenuate history into sapless meagreness.

entries.meaning: (transitive, medicine) To reduce the virulence of a bacterium or virus.
(transitive, electronics) To reduce the amplitude of an electrical, radio, or optical signal.
(brewing) (of a beer) To become less dense as a result of the conversion of sugar to alcohol.
